title: 109_s4072
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gulf Coast Back to Business and Homes Act of 2006". It includes findings related to the Gulf Coast region. Congress finds that 43 percent of businesses that close after a natural disaster never reopen, with an additional 29 percent closing permanently within 2 years. Hurricane Katrina and Rita negatively impacted small businesses in the Gulf Coast, leading to disruptions in commerce. Over 125,000 small and medium-sized businesses in the region were affected by these hurricanes according to the United States Chamber of Commerce. Businesses impacted by Hurricane Katrina are in dire need of increased access to capital and technical assistance to recover and prosper. Without full recovery and prosperity, the Gulf Coast and the rest of the United States will be negatively impacted. The Act defines "Disaster Area" as an area affected by Hurricane Katrina or Rita, "major disaster" as defined in the Stafford Act, and "small business concern" as defined in the Small Business Act. It also includes provisions for Small Business Concern Recovery Grants. The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to appropriate $100,000,000 for the Economic Development Administration to make grants to State agencies in Louisiana, Alabama, Mississippi, and Texas for small businesses affected by Hurricane Katrina or Rita in 2005. The funds will be disbursed based on the number of businesses, residents displaced, and jobs lost in each State. The funds allocated by the Secretary of Commerce for small businesses affected by Hurricane Katrina or Rita in 2005 will be used by States to provide grants to assist businesses in paying employees, bills, making repairs, and addressing financial obligations. The funds allocated by the Secretary of Commerce for small businesses affected by Hurricane Katrina or Rita in 2005 will be used by States to provide grants to assist businesses in paying employees, bills, making repairs, purchasing inventory, and covering additional costs until they can obtain funding through insurance claims, Federal assistance programs, or other sources. States have the flexibility to use their own criteria for grant distribution without being bound by federal eligibility requirements. The Department of Commerce may use up to $1,000,000 to administer grants to designated States for small businesses affected by Hurricane Katrina or Rita in 2005. SEC. 5. DISASTER LOANS AFTER HURRICANE KATRINA OR HURRICANE RITA. After Hurricane Katrina or Hurricane Rita, disaster loans were provided to qualified borrowers in declared disaster areas, allowing for deferment of loan payments. Payments of principal and interest on disaster loans made before December 31, 2006, to qualified borrowers can be deferred for up to 1 year from the date of enactment or loan distribution, with no interest accruing during this period. The Administrator may extend the loan term to 2 years at their discretion. After this period, payments of principal and interest must resume. The Administrator is not allowed to increase collateral requirements. The Administrator may not require collateral for covered loans of up to $35,000 made under specific conditions after Hurricane Katrina or Rita. SEC. 6. WAIVER OF DUPLICATION OF CERTAIN BENEFITS.
